title: Tim spent half of his allowance going to the movies. He washed the family car and earned 8 dollars. What is his weekly allowance if he ended with 11 dollars? - Quora

response.answer_text: 2020–10–29: Maybe it was a long time ago and he had $2 left of his birthday money. Otherwise he tended to live pretty much week to week off of his allowance and small sporadic earnings. (Which were not large enough to report on taxes. In fact he had never earned enough yet to pay taxes anyway.) And maybe he spent $1 at the movies, because it was “buck night” at the drive in, and his girlfriend shared her pop and popcorn. And to keep it simple she even drove and paid for the gas and paid her own $1 to go to the movie. She kept things simple like that because she wanted to watch the movie from the front seat and not feel like she owed Tim anything. (Even though he occasionally did wash her car for free. About the only “generous” thing he would do without having to be asked. But enough about Diane. Word is she eventually got back together with Jack.But I digress.) So the $1 Tim spent at the movies means his allowance was $2. But he only had $1 of that left. He earned $8 washing the family car, as we have been told. So that makes $9.But he ended with $11? Where did the other $2 come from? Oh, yah, remember? There’s the $2 remaining from his birthday money. His 17th. Which was a couple months before, on April 1. So the math checks out. His allowance is $2. (Actually it “was” $2, … back then. It’s been a while. Tim no longer gets an allowance, but he has a small inheritance.) At the rate Tim was going his parents were concerned that he would never move out, or even own his own car. And that’s probably why they never increased his allowance. But Tim eventually grew up and is living a relatively normal life. Relatively, considering that he moved to the city, where his “personal life” is personal, and he is just liberal enough to be on the city council. Fortunately for Tim he “grew up” before the age of video games, (and social media! But I digress … )

He had 22 dollars, spent 11, and ended up with 11. He earned 8 dollars doing one task. It’s not clear that he is only spending from one week of allowance, he could be saving or have made more over time, so the problem is not solveable. If you said “What is his weekly allowance if he started with 0 this week and ended with 11 dollars?” then you can tell that he made 22 dollars this week and the 8 dollars amount is irrelevant or just the last thing he did. Otherwise you simply can’t tell, the question is written wrong or missing a vital detail.

50% of allowance going to movies ($3)50% is the remaining balance ($3)$8 washed the family carfinal unspent money was $11 ( $8 + $3)leaving $3 unaccounted for except it’s 50% of Tim’s allowanceAnswer: Tim’s weekly allowance is just $6
$6. He spent half of his $6 weekly allowance going to the movies, earned $8, and ended with $11.
